questions.question: What is the recommended age for starting screening mammography?
Which of the following is false regarding screening mammography?

options.A: Sensitivity of the test will increase with her age.
options.B: It is best performed in the 2nd half of her menstrual cycle.
options.C: Mediolateral oblique view will show the greatest volume of her breast tissue.
options.D: Craniocaudal view will provide better visualization of the medial aspect of her breast.

questions.explanation: Mammography is best performed in the 1st half of the menstrual cycle, as breast tissue is lessdense in the follicular phase. Also, in the 2nd half of the menstrual cycle, since ovulation occursand there is a chance for pregnancy, the radiation can potentially affect the embryo.The sensitivity of mammography increases with age, as the breast tissue becomes less dense.It involves 2 standard views:Mediolateral oblique (MLO) view- covers a greater volume of breast tissue, including theouter quadrant and the axillary tail of Spence.•upperCraniocaudal (CC) view- provides better visualization of the medial aspect of the breast.Mammography uses low-voltage, high-amperage X-rays. The radiation dose from mammographyis around 0.1 cGy per study.

questions.question: A 50-year-old woman underwent screening mammography. Which of the following findingsin her mammogram is least suggestive of a malignancy?
questions.explanation: Macrocalcification in a lesion is least suggestive of a malignancy. It is commonly seen in benignbreast disorders. Microcalcification (<0.5 mm in diameter) is suggestive of malignancy.Table: Mammographic appearance of benign and malignant massesBelow is an image showing a malignant breast mass with ill-defined, spiculated marginsand microcalcifications.226OpacityCalcificationBreast parenchymaNormalNipple/areolaNormalSkinNormalBenignLow densityHomogenousSmooth marginThin haloMalignantHigh densityNot homogenousIll-defined margin, irregularstellate spiculated margin, comet tailWide haloMacrocalcification (>0.5 mm) Microcalcification (<0.5 mm)Architectural distortionRetractionThickeningCooper ligamentsNormalThickening, increase in numberDuctsNormalSubcutaneous and mammaryNormalFocal dilatationObliterationspace0AB

questions.question: Which pattern of microcalcification seen in a patient's mammography report would indicatethe maximum risk of malignancy?
questions.explanation: Cluster microcalcification in mammography indicates the maximum risk of malignancy.227LinearDiffuseRegionalClusteredSegmental

questions.question: Match the following types of calcifications with the diseases they are associated with.
questions.explanation: Popcorn calcification is seen in fibroadenoma.Lead-pipe/egg-shell calcification is seen in traumatic fat necrosis.Broken-needle type of calcification is seen in duct ectasia.Tea-cup calcification is seen in fibrocystic disease.Popcorn calcification:Lead-pipe/egg-shell calcification:KA228Broken-needle type of calcification:Tea-cup calcification:229

questions.question: A 58-year-old woman presents with complaints of a painless lump in her left breast which shenoticed during a routine self-examination. On palpation, a hard lump with irregular marginsand enlarged left axillary lymph nodes were found. Which among the following is the bestmodality to detect malignancy in her case?
questions.explanation: Tomosynthesis (3D mammography) performed along with conventional 2D mammography is thebest investigation among the given options to detect breast carcinoma.Breast Tomosynthesis is typically performed in conjunction with conventional mammography.Hence, the radiation dose is doubled. However, the accuracy is improved and false positives arelesser. It can be used for dense breasts and those with high-risk factors.Screen-film mammography is the conventional 2D mammography.Digital mammography/full-field digital mammography uses digital technology instead of films.The diagnostic accuracy is similar to that of screen-film mammography. A minor advantage is thegreater accuracy in predicting lesions in dense breasts.Note: Overall, the best modality for detecting breast carcinoma is MRI.The below image shows a comparison of 2D mammogram vs. 3D mammogram:2302DCANCER3D

questions.question: A mammogram done for a 45-year-old female patient with a breast lump was reported asBIRADS category o. What is it suggestive of?
questions.explanation: Category/score o in BIRADS suggests an incomplete assessment.All breast imaging should be reported by BIRADS (breast imaging-reporting and data system).

questions.question: 220A 48-year-old woman with a lump in her right breast was advised to undergo mammographywhich was reported as BIRADS 3. What will be the appropriate next step of management inthis patient?
questions.explanation: A BIRADS score of 3 means that it is probably a benign lesion. The next appropriate step is tofollow up with this patient every 6 months for the next 2 years.During this period, the score can either downgrade to BIRADS 2 or upgrade to BIRADS 4 or 5.

questions.question: An anxious 45-year-old woman presented with complaints of a lump over her left breast for 2months. The patient underwent mammography, and the lump was categorized as BIRADS 4a.What is the likelihood of her lesion being malignant?
questions.explanation: There is a 2-10% likelihood for a lesion with BIRADS 4a to be malignant.BIRADS Categories/GradesGrades 1 and 2: 0% chance of being malignant.Grade 3: >0% but ≤2% chance of being malignantGrade 4:•• 4a: >2 to ≤10% chance of being malignant• 4b: >10 to ≤50% chance of being malignant• 4c: >50 to <95% chance of being malignantGrade 5: 95% chance of being malignant231

questions.question: A 36-year-old pregnant lady was referred to the surgery OPD at 12 weeks of gestation with alump in her right breast for the past 1 month. On examination, a lump of 2 x 1 cm size waspalpated in the upper outer quadrant of the breast. Which of the following investigationswould you initially advise her for the assessment of the breast lump?
questions.explanation: Ultrasonography (USG) is the preferred initial investigation in pregnant women who present witha breast lump. It can differentiate between solid and cystic lesions of the breast and is able todetect abnormal axillary lymph nodes. USG is preferred in women with dense breast tissue suchas:• Pregnant women• Lactating women• Young women (less than 40 years old)Conventional Mammography/ Tomosynthesis with 2D mammography is less useful in pregnantwomen due to the increased density of breast tissue.MRI is not the initial investigation used for the assessment of breast lumps. It can be used incases where metastasis or spread to other breasts is suspected.

questions.question: A USG can detect lymph node metastases in a patient with breast cancer and clinicallynegative lymph nodes by what percentage?
questions.explanation: A USG can detect lymph node metastasis in a patient with clinically negative lymph nodes by50-60%.The clinical determination of axillary lymph node metastases has an accuracy of only 33%.Ultrasound (USG) is more sensitive than physical examination alone in determining axillarylymph node involvement during the preliminary staging of breast carcinoma.Fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) or core biopsy of sonographically indeterminate orsuspicious lymph nodes can provide a more definitive diagnosis than USG alone.Ultrasonography can also be utilized to image the regional lymph nodes in patients with breastcancer. The sensitivity for the status of axillary nodes ranges from 35% to 82% and specificityranges from 73% to 97%.The features of a lymph node involved with cancer on USG include:• Cortical thickening•Change in shape of the node to a more circular appearance• Size larger than 10 mm•Absence of a fatty hilum• Hypoechoic internal echoes

questions.question: Which of the following features on USG will not be suggestive of breast malignancy?

options.D: Lump will be taller than wider

questions.explanation: 232Malignant breast lump on USG, has an ill-defined echogenic halo, is hypoechoic, and the lumpwill be taller than wider. Benign breast lumps have a thin echogenic pseudo-capsule on USG.

questions.question: Ayoung female patient presents to the clinic with a painless lump in her right breast. Sheunderwent breast augmentation surgery 3 years back. Which of the following will be the bestinvestigation to assess the breast tissue in this patient?
questions.explanation: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is the best investigation to assess breast tissue in a patientwith a breast implant.MRI of the breast is also used in:•⚫ Screening of high-risk individuals with a positive family history.• Assessing loco-regional spread (multifocality and multicentricity) of carcinoma.• To differentiate scar from recurrence in women who have had breast conservation surgery forbreast cancer.Option A: Tomosynthesis is not preferred, as radio-opaque implants are usually compressedtogether with the breast tissue, obscuring the visibility and thereby reducing its sensitivity.Option B: Ultrasonography is used as an initial investigation in the evaluation of breastabnormalities in patients with breast implants.Option D: Computed tomography is not routinely used in the evaluation of breast lumps.

questions.question: A 40-year-old woman with an elder sister with BRCA1 gene mutation presented to the OPDwith a normal mammography report. Which of the following is the next preferredinvestigation to further evaluate this patient?
questions.explanation: In the given scenario, since the patient is at high risk for breast malignancy (first degree relativewith BRCA1 gene mutation), MRI followed by trucut biopsy will be the appropriate next step forfurther evaluation.MRI is helpful in the screening of high-risk individuals and is the most sensitive imagingmodality. However, it should be done after initial radiological evaluation, in case the results areinconclusive.American Cancer Society Risk Criteria for Breast Magnetic Resonance Imaging Screening:Women at high lifetime risk (~20%-25% or greater) of breast cancer-••Known BRCA1 or BRCA2 gene mutationFirst-degree relatives with BRCA1 or BRCA2 gene mutation, but have not had genetic testingthemselves.• Radiation therapy to the chest between the ages of 10 and 30 years• Li-Fraumeni syndrome or Cowden syndrome or a first-degree relative with one of thesesyndromes.Women with a personal history of breast cancer, ductal carcinoma in situ, lobular carcinoma insitu, atypical ductal hyperplasia, or atypical lobular hyperplasia, are at a moderately increasedlifetime risk for breast cancer.233Options A & D: Breast tomosynthesis or repeat mammography is not preferred as the nextinvestigation in high-risk patients.Option C: Trucut biopsy will be done following MRI in high-risk patients.

questions.question: 222A postmenopausal woman who was on HRT for the past 2 years, presented with a 4 x 3cmlump over the upper outer quadrant of the left breast. On examination, a peau d'orangeappearance was seen and a hard and fixed lump was palpated over the breast. Which of thefollowing is the investigation of choice to confirm the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.explanation: The history and physical examination point towards a diagnosis of breast malignancy. Theinvestigation of choice for confirmation of breast carcinoma is trucut biopsy/core-needle biopsy.An excisional biopsy can be done, in case it is inconclusive.Trucut needle biopsy permits the analysis of breast tissue architecture. A 14 G- 16 G needle isused. The advantages include a low complication rate, minimal scarring, and a lower cost ascompared to excisional breast biopsy.Fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is a cytological investigation and, hence, not theinvestigation of choice. A 22-30 G needle is used for FNAC.Trucut biopsy is preferred over FNAC as it:• Allows a definitive preoperative diagnosis• Differentiates between DCIS and invasive disease.Allows the tumor to be stained for receptor status, which is important for starting neoadjuvanttherapy.Image-guided biopsy is used only in the case of non-palpable lesions.

questions.question: As a surgery resident, which of the following will you perform in a patient with suspectedbreast malignancy as part of the triple assessment?
questions.explanation: Triple assessment in relation to breast carcinoma includes the following:•Clinical assessment includes both history and clinical examination• Radiological imaging, including ultrasonography (USG) and/or mammography•Histopathological examination (HPE), including fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) and/orTru-Cut biopsyThe positive predictive value of the triple assessment is 99.9%.Note: Bailey & Love 27th Ed mentions that clinical assessment, radiological imaging, andHPE constitute triple assessment. However, clinical assessment includes both history and clinicalexamination. Hence, history is a part of the triple assessment.

questions.question: An actress with bilateral silicone breast implants presents for regular follow-up. Onradiological evaluation, she was found to have signs suggestive of intracapsular breastimplant rupture. Which of the following named signs will you see on imaging?
questions.explanation: Linguine sign (on MRI) and Stepladder sign (on USG) are specific for intracapsular breast implantrupture.234After implantation of a silicone or saline breast implant, a fibrous capsule (scar) forms around theimplant shell. In an intracapsular rupture, the contents of the implant are contained by thefibrous scar, while the free-floating shell appears as a group of wavy lines (like the Italian linguinepasta as shown below). Hence, this has been termed the "linguine sign".ET:8LStepladder sign (seen on USG) is identified as multiple, discontinuous, parallel, linear echoes inthe lumen as shown below.235ABSnowstorm sign (seen on USG) is seen in extracapsular rupture of breast implant.Comet tail sign is a finding that can be seen on chest CT. The comet-tail sign is produced by thedistortion of vessels and bronchi that lead to an adjacent area of round atelectasis, which is themass. The bronchovascular bundles appear to be pulled into the mass and resemble a comet tail.Note: Detection of intracapsular silicone ruptures is almost impossible on mammography.

questions.question: A woman came with complaints of breast pain following surgery. Her MRI is shown below.What is the likely diagnosis?223[R][L]
questions.explanation: The above image shows curvilinear hypointense lines (arrows) in the left breast implant indicativeof the collapsed shell floating in the silicone gel. This is called the linguine sign that is seenin intra-capsular rupture of a breast implant.After implantation of a silicone or saline breast implant, a fibrous capsule (scar) forms around theimplant shell. In an intracapsular rupture, the contents of the implant are contained by thefibrous scar, while the shell appears as a group of wavy lines.This has been termed the "linguine sign" and has been most commonly described with MRimaging.Multiple hyperintense foci on T2-weighted images are sometimes found within the implantlumen. These findings are referred to as the salad oil sign or droplet sign.Indications for breast MRI:•Screening for DCIS in high-risk patients• Evaluation of breast implants•Evaluation of breast scar tissue versus recurrent tumors.Ultrasound is the preferred modality of imaging in suspected cases of extracapsular rupture. Thesnowstorm sign on USG is seen in extracapsular rupture.236

questions.question: A 50-year-old female patient presents with a 4*3cm irregular mass in the upper outerquadrant of the right breast, which is not fixed to the skin or the chest wall. A lymph node of2cm is palpated in the right axilla. No mass is palpated in the opposite breast. Which of thefollowing investigations would you perform on this patient?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of breast malignancy with locoregional spread withunlikely distant metastasis. For further evaluation of this lesion, bilateral mammography, abiopsy of the breast mass and a USG-guided biopsy of the suspicious lymph node need to beperformed in order to determine staging and decide on further management.Statement 2: PET Scan is usually performed in advanced cases of breast cancer. It is not routinelyused in the assessment of locoregional disease.Statement 1: Diagnostic mammography is used to evaluate women with abnormal findings such asa breast mass or nipple discharge. Mammography is more accurate than clinical examination forthe detection of early breast cancers. Mammographic features suggestive of breast cancer includea solid mass with or without stellate features, microcalcifications, irregular soft tissue shadow,spiculations and duct distortion.Statement 3: Pathological diagnosis of carcinoma is made by a core needle biopsy (tru-cut biopsy)or fine-needle aspiration before any type of treatment is started.Statement 4: The presence or absence of axillary lymph node involvement in breast cancer is oneof the most important prognostic factors for determining staging and treatment.Ultrasound-guided lymph node biopsy should be done in patients with suspicious or clinicallypalpable lymph nodes.Ultrasound features suggestive of breast cancer include a hypoechoic, irregular mass withindistinct, angulated or spiculated margins, acoustic shadowing, ductal extension and a branchedpattern of mass.

questions.question: A 22-year-old woman is found to have the BRCA1 mutation. She got herself tested after hermother's death due to breast cancer with a BRCA1 mutation. At what age and with whichmodality would you start breast cancer screening in this patient?
questions.explanation: Patients with BRCA mutations or positive known first-degree family history are consideredhigh-risk patients. These patients need to undergo annual screening MRI + Mammogram from theage of 25yrs.Patients with a family history of breast cancer but no known gene mutation should also startscreening before 40 years. Screening should begin 10 years before the earliest age of diagnosis ofbreast cancer in the first-degree relative. E.g- If the mother was detected with breast cancer at 40years of age, the daughter should start screening by the age of 30 years.High-risk patients for breast cancer:• Women with a known BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutation• Two first-degree relatives with breast cancers with or without gene mutations•Women with a history of chest irradiation between the ages of 10 and 30• 2 or more cases of breast cancer < 50 years old in the family•Mutation (or a first-degree relative with a mutation) in the TP53 or PTEN genes237

questions.question: A young woman with a distant breast cancer relative comes to you in the clinic. You areadvising her to practice self-examination of her breasts. Which of the following statements isincorrect regarding this practice?

options.A: It should be done once a month, every month
options.B: Ideally, be done between the 3rd to 6th day of the menstrual cycle
options.C: It should only be done while standing
options.D: The examination should be done by using the middle three fingerpads

questions.explanation: Self-examination of breasts can be done while standing or lying down.It should be ideally be done once a month, every month between the 3rd to 6th day of themenstrual cycle. If the periods are irregular or the patient is post-menopausal, then the patientcan pick any day of the month.It can be done any time of the day while showering, dressing, standing, or lying down at night.Steps of the self-examination:• Visual inspection: See for any abnormalities, like shape, size, dimpling, puckering of the skin,nipple discharge, etc.• Manual inspection: It is done by using the middle three fingerpads. Feel for any lumps.Techniques used are (either one of them):•⚫ Horizontal stripes method• Vertical stripes method• Dial clock methodBe sure to check under the areola and press the nipple gently to check for any discharge.CirclesLines238
